div1.p: Hench discusses the location of the original fever charts. He also comments on life in the army.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 16, 1942
div1.p:
You were very kind to send me your
comments on Dr Ames' notation re Dean.
Im delighted to have the so called
“original” YF charts (so called by D. Ames)
but I still wonder where the real original
ones are. Do you suppose they were thrown
away when they were copied? The search
for them has been (& still is) intriguing.
I certainly couldn't find them in Washington.
of course that genial gentleman George
Carroll may have them. I wonder if
I'll ever be able to crack his psychopathic
reserve (paranoid type).

I'm pleased that you were so interested
in your own charts. I don't wonder either.

Well I've been in the army 11 days
now. It seems much longer. For a happy
married & professional man to leave
so much behind, any life demands great
adjustments. I was pretty disconsolate
the first few days but am delighted to
find myself adjusting satisfactory
most of the men Ive met are fine men. One
however is slightlyquite (adjective altered on second
reading!!) sadistic but I can
take it.

Friday midnight an emergency call
came into an hospital. Four of us answered
it with 3 ambulances & went to the
scene of the crash of an army bomber which
fell 15 miles from here. We hoped to find
some survivors but found only 9 horrbly
mangled bodies It was a ghostly sight
as some were crushed to pulp! The
plane was shattered to bits. I could never
believe such demolution were possible.
Except for a large piece of fuselage
the rest was in pieces - a million -
hardly more than 1-5 pounds in weight
scattered all over the landscape-

So already Ive seen a ghostly
fragment of the horrible by - products of
war. We must win!!!
div1.closer: Always gratefully & sincerely Philip S Hench new & strange title - Lt. Col. M C.
